I wouldn't say that it proved that the theory of evolution is wrong, more like the theory needs some adjustments. Just like when it was first discovered that planets revolved around the Sun, astronomers thought that the orbits were perfectly circular, but Johannes Kepler discovered that they were elliptical.

No body debates if, say a tiger is a carnivore or a herbivore since it is a proven fact that the former is true. But the debate about evolution never cease since it is impossible to prove biological system evolve gradually. Alas macroevolution is just another faith held dear by a number of human, just like any religious beliefs. There is no absolute truth about it, your truth is not necessary my truth. So dont force the issue.

Funny true Bombadier beetle story.

I had to collect and pin bugs for a biology college course a few years back. In order to kill and preserve the insects, I would place them in a jar that had been filled with a toxic gas that killed them and dehydrated their corpses. In order to "process" more than one insect at a time, (I had to leave the bugs in overnight to ensure that they were fully dead and not just KO'd) I would use those little plastic condiment cups you get at some restaurants, poke holes in the lids, and store the bugs in there as I gassed them. Turns out, some of these insects were bombardier beetles (likely the same species or genus a the ones shown since this happened not too far from Berkeley).
How do I know? For one, they had that same black and orange coloration pattern. For another, they sprayed like crazy when they died. I'm not sure if it was only because of the chemicals they produced or if the toxic gas played a role but something crazy happened; the condiment containers started to melt. It was as if I had placed the cups in a microwave. They sagged under their own weight and the lid fused with the rim of the cup. I actually had to cut the cups open to get the insects out.

Hope someone finds this as interesting as I did.
PS: I do/did feel guilty going out of my way to kill all those bugs. Don't think me some sort of anti-insect Nazi or something.

Only problem I see with the theory presented on how the beetle developed is that there isn't much reason for that beetle to be housing those chemicals in it's body in the first place, if a beetle had already developed into a beetle, why would it genetically take a risk of incorporating a useless chemical that wouldn't pay off for generations of evolution? I would think it would continue to improve on it's already developed strengths--why waste time and precious life? There's no way the beetle had foresight into what the chemicals could be used for in the future.

I just wonder why people always talk as though evolution has a mind of it's own, driving creatures to evolve in very useful and intelligent ways. Obviously, the creatures themselves aren't the intelligent ones making the genetic changes happen, but evolution is supposed to be an explanation, not a driving force. What tells the genetic codes to change? Genetic codes/makeup are not intelligent, either.

We often have to personify evolution and genes to explain what is happening. But then we rely on that personification as though it were actually happening--yet personification is a figure of speech! But if we do believe that evolution is personified, what does that say, what does that mean? Do we believe evolution is sentient?

the reason why this defies evolution is that the complicated system offers no benefit without a complete system. Theres plenty of similar examples in nature but few so clear as this beetle.

So the beetle needs to grow an organ that produces a chemical. Then it needs another organ for a second chemical. Then it needs a new enzyme to neutralize them. Then it needs another enzyme to neutralize the neutralizer and a seperate organ to hold it. Its body needs to produce these all together and working in sync.

But were not done yet!

Lets assume all of these form in perfect harmony to provide a great defense and hundreds of its siblings shared the exact same mutation. How does it work? So now you need a new orafice. Then you need to grow new muscles to spray it. You need to grow new muscles to spray the deneutralizing enzyme.

Not one of these offers a benefit without the whole system. So in theory all these organs and chemicals produced would become vestigial or at the very least not have any selective reason to move forward in the species until the entire system is intact.

Having a skin that can withstand fire doesnt suddenly mean you grow a complex fire spitting cannon. Some animals may have evolved but this is not one of them. So logic should follow that if there are some animals that could not have evolved then the theory cannot not be applied to all creatures.

Its very unscientific to be faced with clear evidence against a theory and hold to it with with religious zeal. Either scrap the theory or understand that it is either incomplete or only applies to specific situations.

This is a great example of how the argument is framed in a straw man type way. She seems to imply that because there was a way this could have a evolved, that those people who are less on board with evolution are wrong. But that point is, evolution happens, anyone who denies that is blind, it's the fact that something so improbable as this happened which is cause to question the basis of the theory, not whether or not the theory is "true" or "false".
The explanation is simple: God created it that way! That's much easier to understand than trying to explain it through the very faulty evolution lookingglass.
